intro: Carex cuprina var. subcontigua, commonly known as the narrowleaf sedges, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes grass-like plants commonly found in wet or moist habitats. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves that are typically arranged in dense, cylindrical clusters. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are characteristic of the sedge family. This variety is often found in wetlands, stream banks, and other moist environments where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
